Fact.origin: [Latin factum deed, real happening, something done, from neuter of factus , past participle of facere to do, make]

1.definition: something that has actual existencea matter of objective reality

2.definition: any of the circumstances of a case that exist or are alleged to exist in realitya thing whose actual occurrence or existence is to be determined by the evidence presented at trial see alsoat,at,compare,

adjudicative fact.definition: a fact particularly related to the parties to an esp. administrative proceeding comparein this entry

collateral fact.definition: a fact that has no direct relation to or immediate bearing on the case or matter in question comparein this entry

constitutional fact.definition: a fact that relates to the determination of a constitutional issue (as violation of a constitutional right) used esp. of administrative findings of fact

evidentiary fact.definition: a fact that is part of the situation from which a case arises and that is established by testimony or other evidence called alsocomparein this entry

legislative fact.definition: a fact of general social, economic, or scientific relevance that does not change from case to case comparein this entry

material fact.definition: a fact that affects decision making

sub_terms.a: a fact upon which the outcome of all or part of a lawsuit depends
sub_terms.b: a fact that would influence a reasonable person under the circumstances in making an investment decision (as in purchasing a security or voting for a corporate officer or action)

ul·ti·mate fact.definition: [əl-ti-mət-]a conclusion of law or esp. mixed fact and law that is necessary to the determination of issues in a case and that is established by evidentiary facts comparein this entry
